div.l: Til that al most / al empty is the tonne
The strem of lyf / droppeth on the chyme
The sely tonge / may wel rynge ⁊and chymbe
Of wrechidnesses / that passed is ful yore
With olde folk / save dotage / ther is no more
Whan that our / oost hadde herd this sermoıı̄unyng
He gan to speke / as lordly / as a kyng
He seide what amoıı̄unteth al this wit
What shal we speke / alday of holy writ
The devil maad / a reve for to preche
Or of a soutere / a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thi tale / ⁊and tarye nat the tyme
Loo depforde / and it is half weye to pryme
Loo greenwich / that many a shrewe is Inne
It were al tyme thi tale for to bigynne
Now sires / qduod this oswold the reeve
I pray yow alle / that ye yow nat greeve
Thouh I Answere / ⁊and somdel set his howve
For lefful is / with fors / fors of to showve
This dronken millere / hath I told vs heere
How that bigiled / was a Carpenteere
ꝐPararauenture in skorn / for I am oon
And bi your leve / I shal hym qvite a noon
Riht in his cherlissh termes / wol I speke
I pray to god his necke / mot I breke
He can se wel / in myn eye a stalke
But in his owne / he kan nat fynde a balke
At trompyngtoıı̄un nat fer fro Cambregge
Ther goth a brook / and ouer that a brigge
Vp on the which brook / stst ther stant a mille
And this is werrey soth / that I yow telle
A myller was ther / dwellyng many a day
As any pecok / he was stowt and gay
Pipen he cowde / and fisshen ⁊and nettis bete
